reviewText:
For anyone hoping to find a point and click sequel to the first game, I'm thrilled they abandon it for what we got with the sequel. Finding Teddy 2 is a fun, 2D side-scrolling adventure game in a mapless MetroidVania style but with controls taken from Zelda 2. This feels so familiar, fun and fresh for every retro gamer that grew up in the 80s or 90s. There's no nostalgia here outside of the Adventure of Link poster on the wall, Finding Teddy 2 offers an new 20 hour adventure that relies heavily on exploration, discovery, combat and traversal. Its an enjoyable experience through its entire beautiful world. From an underground river to the furthest reaches of the heavens, its well worth your time to explore.

There's so much to explore and discover. You'll always find a subtle goal of what to do next, but to know where to go. To explore a new place, you'll need to remember and old one. You're never guided or hand held. You won't ever find a map, so beware, you'll need to make your own or just take screenshots to remember a place or something important. That's all you need to make it easier on yourself.

You never get an explanation on why you are in this strange new world. You simply travel into your basement after a night of playing video games and you're teleported down. The environments are beautiful and marvelously detailed with an retro pixelated look. The world has a sense of size and scope when the camera is pulled out. You'll see your character so tiny on the screen compared to a massive guardian that's as tall as a skyscraper. For tight corridors, the camera will zoom in tight to give a sense of cluster phobia.

Like other MetroidVania games, you'll explore a vast foreboding world, starting with the outside and inside of a castle. Over time, you'll gather books that will teleport you to four unique areas. You'll visit a rugged forest, a dreary swamp, a charming winter wonderland and a happy hunting ground that hides volcanic caves within. Each of these four areas has a palace with its own theme and boss.

In each of these areas, you'll come across towns with inhabitants that speak only in musical melodies. Each word can amount to two, three or four notes. Each word gets stored in your Lexicom so you can use them later as codes to open doors or speak to palace guardians. Its the musical melodies that make up the majority of puzzles in Finding Teddy. Since the game is about exploration and discovery, you need to find all twelve tones to your instrument from treasure chests scattered throughout the world.

As you search through the world, you'll hear melodies over the subtle ambient music. When you perform the same melody, you'll discover a firefly as a sort of hidden collectable that will unlock an extra far deeper in the game. You'll need to use the same play by ear technique to unlock big golden treasure boxes in each palace with each containing a new ability to traverse the world.

You'll find hieroglyphics in palaces that will teach you necessary melodies. You can shift ice crystals from cold to hot and vise versa. Heating them up will melt ice blocks surrounding doors, chests or even blocking paths. One quick melody can subdue flower petals that have overgrown doorways and platforms. The petals will grow back, so it turns into a timer for certain sections. The real downfall is having to use the quick melody over and over again for several flower platforms.

The game is easy to control with a 360 controller and keyboard support. You have buttons to run, play music, jump and attack. For anyone used to a whip or a gun in your MetroidVania games, you might not like how short your sword is. I didn't find any issue with it though, because you have a lot of control over it from the start, you can downward or upward thrust enemies easily to keep you moving. You can also double tap a direction to start running, which I thought was an issue, because I'd accidentally run into something. I'd like to be able to turn off the double tap. There are vines you can easily go up or down, probably the easiest game to climb things quickly. Floors you can drop through and one way platforms to restrict as an entrance only. You can even crouch to attack or crawl through tight areas. Even walk through walls to find secret areas! If its all been done before, Finding Teddy 2 pulls it off to perfection.

There are four traversal abilities, a duck inner tube to float through water, a double jump that temporarily transforms you to an angel, a wall jump and a downward thrust that will break special blocks. The bosses of each palace require you to use your new skills. Everything from floating in the water to dodge projectiles to wall jumping in order to avoid a giant snake made of crystals. While all of the bosses are interesting, none is that difficult. Its a fun game so nothing is ever too daunting. Each ability allows you to move not only further in the castle that holds this world together, but you'll have to back track to find other things. The further you go, the more books you'll find to enter new areas.

Your menu has placeholders for everything that you'll find. Items to give to people, 25 collectable items in each of the four themed areas. There are colored orbs, each one turns hollow squares into blocks that you can platform on. These orbs can also unlock colored doors. Keys will of course unlock locked doors. Each defeated boss earns you one of four colored eggs which is your ultimate goal to the final boss. Its all about finding what it takes to get you through the next door.

There is a big variety of enemies that will keep you on your toes. Even a variety of blobs become a threat. Standard yellow blobs give way to electric blobs that will hurt you if you attack them at inopportune moments. Fire blobs that leave trails of fire and then explode into flames when destroyed. Several foes have shields so you'll need to attack from behind, above or any place you can time it right. They're all intelligent and will block accordingly.

As you defeat enemies, you'll collect marbles and health. The marbles are a currency that let you buy things from the world's only store inside the castle library. There's a brief selection of sword and defense upgrades, a health sphere, a health container that gives you more health, a ring with mysterious powers and a death diamond. While Finding Teddy 2 is a forgiving game with plenty of health, death explodes your character, including losing a lot of marbles in the process. Each death sends you back to an entry point of the area or palace. Having the death diamond resurrects you where you are with half your health bar full. A nice thing about the store is you can put a down payment on an item, so if you die, you'll have less marbles.

For anyone looking for replay value, you can unlock a new game plus by making it through the game. It doesn't stop there, because you keep unlocking more new game pluses. There are tons of secrets that will have you solving melody puzzles for hours as you search and listen for firefly tones. Its a wonderful game for explorers and completionists to pour time into. A fun game just to move around and beautiful to look around too.

I think the only thing holding this game back is its music is ambient. Its still good and makes an effort to sooth and relax you. The issue is it doesn't have a big, bold, upbeat catchy soundtrack like Castlevania or Metroid. I do understand the music needs to be subtle to add to the atmosphere and ensure that you hear the melodies, but it can be a detriment to just how great this game is.

In conclusion, outside of a few issues, Finding Teddy 2 is a great game that's well worth $15 or even $25. Its not a difficult game, its a joy to play and exactly what I was looking for. Its beautiful, immersive and even if a bit time consuming having to scour every area over and over again to use every new item or ability. I'd also like to thank Delphine of Plug In Digital for the copy.

reviewText:
Recommended for Zelda 2 fans, with some reservations

Positives:
-Fantastic art and animations
-has all the classic metroidvania staples, well designed levels, secrets, places that are locked until you find the appropriate items
-Puzzles and recorder device are smart and well implimented
-decent and fitting soudtrack, good sound effects

Neutral:
-Hard difficulty
-No guide or explanation, exploration and problem solving encouraged.
-You lose your currency upon dying.  Some will appreciate this as a challenge.  I f'n hated it.

Negatives:
-You'll need a controller as button mapping cannot be changed, and on a keyboard it's almost impossible to play.  This should really be pointed out.
-No Map-Why???
-Your sword is tiny.  It's more like a shovel.  You have to be two pixels from an enemy to connect.  I found this super frustrating when...

-THIS IS BY FAR THE WORST THING: The controls for the most part are fine and responsive, but pushing forward twice causes a dash.  So when you are trying to get close to an enemy or platforming, you end up dashing into an enemy or off the cliff.  When your sword is friggin tiny you find yourself getting hurt by otherwise easy to kill enemys.  PLEASE CHANGE THIS!

-Its very easy to miss things, because the backgrounds, while beautiful, are very subtle.  I didn't realize there was a store till after resorting to a walkthrough.  By then I had died a few times reducing the $500 I had to a little over a hundred.  Because...
-When you die you lose HALF your money.  Saving for that upgrade?  Better not kick the bucket!

Despite all those negatives, It's stll a lush, challenging, beautiful game.  It's frustrating that some of the difficulty lies with the controls, but I'm sure I'll keep going if I don't break  my controller first.
I'd say 8.5/10

If you like this game I highly recommend Elliot Quest.  Very similar style and gameplay.
voteText: 44 of 47 people (94%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Although a departure from the original. Finding Teddy 2, manages to keep the magic and atmosphere of its former. However, new elements and ideas have been added and refined. The music note system which was fairly tricky in the first game. Has been streamlined with a dictionary and simple to use interface. The game has also adopted a new Metroidvania element. Where parts of the game unlock as you gain access to new abilities and powers. The difficulty one found in the original can also be found here. With no maps or little narrative to guide you. The games speed lies solely in your hands for discovery. While this does lead to backtracking and even sometimes feeling lost. There is usually something to be explored or a hint to be given.
The combat in Finding Teddy 2 is difficult and rewards careful players. Those looking to hack and slash there way through the game quickly will quickly find themselves dead. With bosses, plenty of gameplay, Steamy goodness and more. Finding Teddy 2 is a sequel that holds up to the original and brings something fresh to the table.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/QNPGVzczmIQ
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr
voteText: 28 of 29 people (97%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
========================================

Vince Rowe ReviewsSaving the Industry one Game at a Time!

[YouTube Link]   [Curation Link]

========================================

A good little platformer that's more of an Adventure Puzzle game than an Action RPG. I'd recommend it to those that are interested in it but be warned because I had to resort to a walkthrough about 30 minutes in... You'll enjoy it more and more as you progress!

Verdict - 7.2/10 - Good GameGraphics - 9/10 - Amazing
Music - 8/10 - Great
Sound - 8/10 - Great
Combat - 5/10 - Average
Level Design - 8/10 - Great
Story - 5/10 - Average

Pros:+ Pixel Art Graphics
+ Amazing Animations (The first guardian looks awesome)
+ Average Combat
+ Some really well-done Boss Fights
+ Great Platforming
+ Good Level Design
+ Good Atmosphere
+ Good Music
+ Good Sound
+ Decent Progression
+ Lots of collectables in the game (Great for completionists!)
+ Achievements and Trading Cards
+ Reasonable Price

Cons:- - Little-no guidance, frustrating at times
- - Some parts of Combat are frustrating
- Little-no storyline (As far as I'm aware)


Additional Information:
Like I said, I actually had to look up a walkthrough after playing this game for 30 minutes, it really doesn't give the player any information at all. The information is available in places, for example the NPCs do give you some of the information but other times I had no idea what I was doing, it took me ages to get the hand of things and I started to get frustrated with the game because of it... Which is a major gripe in this game, it's a shame really because otherwise it flows quite well.

The graphics are pretty awesome, the actual style of the graphics is kind of basic; it's just your average Pixel Art but it's the animations that make it awesome, some of the combat animations make it fun to attack and the animation on the first Guardian is absolutely awesome and really well done.

The combat is... Kind of... 'Meh' to be honest, some of the enemies feel clunky to fight and there's no knockback - from what I've seen - in this game at all, once an enemy starts charging their attack there's nothing you can do to interrupt it, in addition just touching an enemy causes damage to the player, this is find for enemies such as Slimes but warrior based enemies with weapons is just plain irritating, especially after they have already charged and commenced their attack... All of this really makes the combat feel; clunky at best... There is a shop where you can purchase items like a better sword and armour as well as a few other items which I have no idea what they do, it gives a small sense of progression but it's not a major part of the game. There are some Great mechanics in the combat though, such as the shielding mechanic but at the moment this isn't really expanded upon well.

The actual platforming of the game is actually really well done and the movement is flows really well, it's a shame that it's all let down by the 'average at best' combat...

The first one - as far as I know - was a point and click adventure game, and it feels like Finding Teddy 2 is very much the same but in a platformer style format. It's not the best platformer but it does feel like a pretty good 'point and click'...

Overall I did have fun with this game after I knew what I was doing but I'd advice you to read a guide for the first few levels because this game does absolutely no hand-holding what-so-ever.



My suggestions to the Developer - remove the pause that occurs when you fall too fast, it really removes the flow of the platforming. Make the attack range just a tad larger and allow some of the charge attacks to be interrupted. Lower the amount of sliding the character does so it doesn't feel like an Ice Rink and the game will feel much tighter and more solid.

Link to my Curations.

reviewText:
A GIRL SITS IN THE DARK playing a video game one Summer evening.  It looks alot like another game you may have seen before, or perhaps even played yourself.  Abruptly the strong glow of the television cuts out and shrouds the room and its contents into shadow.  Upset by this, the girl tosses her controller to the carpet, stands, and roots arond in a nearby chest -- eventually pulling out a small dagger and green coloured shield.  Now so equipped, the girl traverses the disparate rooms of the unpopulated house with the resolve to find out the cause of this unwelcomed interruption.  In the basement she finds something strange... and peculiar.  The nebulous shade of a teddy bear floating next to an open doorway full of bright light beckons the girl to follow it into the luminance beyond the portal.  She renews her grip upon her dagger and shield, descends the basement steps, and begins her adventure.

Okay so, I will start by giving the obvious thing away.  This is - through and through - a METROIDVANIA.  So if you know what that phrase means and arent put off by it but rather all-the-more intrigued, then I can happily report that you should BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY!

Here are some reasons WHY:

The Music, Sound Design, Graphics -- basically anything aesthetically pleasing about a video game is done SO, VERY, well here.  This game has Syphony of The Night mixed with FEZ levels of graphical splendor that just oozes over your eyeballs and coaxes your brain into telling you only to simply nod and go, Wow...".  It's a seriously gorgeous game.

It also has a very maze-like approach to level design and
date: without the help of a map
recommended: you really have to use your brain-box to sort it all out for yourself.  Navigating can be a bit of a nightmare because of this mapless system
hoursPlayed: however I never begrudged the game this missing feature because it forcefully got me to explore things more than I already had and to also stumble upon numerous  secrets and to amass more currency via slaying monsters to spend in the vendor's shop.\n\nAs far as I can tell the game is made by non-english speakers
voteText: and as such
helpfulPercent: the whole thing has this theme of non verbal communication that is rather charming and it only ends up adding to the overall mystique of the world in general.  The only downside to this is that when there is text
votesHelpful: there are several typos and odd sentances that end up occuring here and there but
votesTotal: this is nothing that a patch won't eventually fix.\n\nFinding Teddy 2 is exploration
commentsCount: it's lyrical puzzle solving.  All to the waxing of a beautiful soundtack
column16: and stunning graphics.  It's also pretty hard and doesn't hold your hand through the puzzles.  I found myself getting stuck for small pockets of time and having the game test me to see if I had indeed been paying attension or not.\n\nSeriously
column17:
if you want to relive the good old days and with a little bit of what contemporary PIXEL technology has to offer... what are you waiting for.

HIGHLY RECCOMENDED!  A game of this type hasn't been done THIS well in some time.

Can't wait for the THIRD one!"

reviewText:
Hard to recommend in its current state.

I love the idea of the game: A strong girl running around Zelda 2 style collecting powerups and items that will help her navigate the world. The art and animation is wonderful. I love the idea of music/notes to pass through major unlockable areas.

However, the world makes no consistent sense, and there's no mapping.

Mapping: Many moden games like this have auto-mapping to help keep track of where all the twisting branching areas go. There's just too many areas and doors to simply memorize" it. I'm probably less than 1/4 into the game but have already surpassed like 1.5 Metroids worth of maps and corridors. Knowing that now
date: it's okay; I've busted out paper and pen for when I can't seem to get any further
recommended: and carefully take notes. But this is jarring when you fist experience it.\n\nConsistent Sense: Nothing seems to make sense. The hub-world doesn't make sense. None of the equipment you pick up or purchased is explained at all. I have a ring! No idea what it does. I upgraded to cute blue oeveralls; they seem to provide no protection bonus. I collected Eggplants
hoursPlayed: Scarabs and Snowflakes: I'm hours into the game but have no idea what they're for! In my inventory I have sunglasses and christmas ornaments
voteText: but no idea what they're for. And on and on.\n\nThe discussion boards are flooded with the same questions over and over: Using the shield
votesHelpful: how to use the books as warp gates (this is one of the most intregal features of the game early on
votesTotal: and there's no explanation given for it. The only way to know how to proceed is to check the answer in the Discussion board... What the heck??).\n\nUltimately
votesFunny: the above two points (complex maps that require hand-mapping; and no sense or guidance on objects or their uses) lead to far more frustration than fun. I've gone through The Talos Project without many hints
commentsCount: so I know my way around puzzle games... and yet I find myself stumped regularly
column16: with no guidance as to where to go for the next hint/clue/action... Have spent more time backtracking in this game than making forward progress!\n\nSo
column17: currently I'm about halfway through the game. I'm of equal parts joy and frustration. The art

reviewText:
[A quick rant praise review mindsplosion]

Finding Teddy 2 is a brilliant mix of:
Castlevania, Zelda 2, Metroid, FEZ, Ufouria (NES)

The game's got some really pleasing aesthetics and consistent art direction. The worlds and areas are really diverse and filled with small details, secrets and gives a great sense of exploration. They all have their own little personality too. Music and sound effects are made really well and it'll definitely be a soundtrack I'll chill out and listen to every now and then.

The FEZ mention is because it's the first game since I brought out a pen and paper and actually had fun doing that old school" and also listening to things in the world that are of importance and can be crucial for going forwards.

I immediately got into the controls with ease
date: this might be due to finishing Zelda 2 countless times in my youth and recently last year. There's an enemy straight out of that game as well which was nice to see actually
hoursPlayed: blue or red knights) gets a warm welcome back from me oddly enough :)\n\nBut you won't have a helping hand or a tutorial guiding you hence the slight FEZ comparison above
voteText: though I personally have no issues with it. I love the feeling when you're frustrated
helpfulPercent: confused or just impatient and you solve some cryptic puzzle without a walkthrough etc. it's just amazing and really makes you appreciate it a whole lot more in my opininon.\n\nCompared to other games today where I'm tired of following a linear tutorial that's supposed to teach you the basics (but you'll most likely forget ~50% of it depending on how advanced it is
votesHelpful: and still figure out the rest on your own anyways) and at the end of it you'll get a pointless achievement - no thanks.\n\nI'd take Finding Teddy 2-style no holding hands type of exploration any day over some uninspired dumbed down guidance in a game that's supposed to make you feel good at the game. Though some people act like they're on digital cocaine and the social media obsessions eff up their nervous systems thus needing everything perfect (and achievements to feel like they're doing something) and 100% walkthrough'd provided at release these days

let's cut the rant already befeore this turns into some Hunter S. Thompson impersonation.

reviewText: As someone who has played almost every Metroidvania on Steam, this one is pretty good.  The game just drops you into the world and turns you loose.  A lot of people seem to take issue with this approach, but I like the fact that the game pushes you to explore and think.  There is a minimal amount of explanation and the player has to figure out everything.   It doesn't treat you like an idiot, and its rewarding to figure out some of the game's puzzles and progress.   There is no in-game map,  but it's not that big of a problem.  There's a lot of hidden secrets and the game has many of the standard MV upgrades you have to find (double jump, swim etc.)\n\nThe default controls are a little weird as other have said, so keyboard play is awkward at first.   After the first hour though I was fine

reviewText:
If you like Zelda games, you should try Finding Teddy 2!
i haven't played a game like this for... many years. The atmosphere is gorgeous, puzzles are challenging and there's a lot (I mean A LOT) of secrets you probably won't find if you rush the game.

It seems to be a little hard at first: There is no tutorials, little assistance. But hey! It's like these old games you played when you were a kid in which clues were very rare and you probably spent a lot of time to find the solution. Once you will understand this, the game will be easier.

reviewText:
If you enjoy a good action platformer along the same lines as Metroid or the DS castlevania games then you'll definitely enjoy Finding Teddy 2. It has the same kind of style but puts its own little twist into everything..

It really seems like it would be those games if being seen through the eyes of a child. For example, in order to go in water effectively in one of the castlevania's, you needed a scale.  In this, you need one of those water ring duckies.

The game in terms of text on the screen is quite bare. It doesn't say what an item is when you pick it up and the only time any dialogue text appears is when you meet with the inhabitants. You yourself don't speak..technically. Along the way, you pick up an object called the Musicom which lets you play 'words' and by words, I mean music tones which everybody speaks in. Think of it as the ocarina from Zelda but you're making words with the notes.

If there was anything I had to complain about this game, it'd DEFINITELY be the slime blobs in the third and fourth worlds. The ones that electricify themselves so you can't hit them. Now this is an enemy we know from every game. You just have to wait for it to be done. That's just the problem. Depending on how you move around him, he will just keep reactivating this 'shield' and basically make themselves unhittable forever. They should only do it based on a time limit. LIke they only do it every 10 seconds or something like that.

The other thing would be one of the doors in the star road place. (The place you can get to with all four orbs.) It's the top right door with all the spike balls, flame guys and stuff.

If the people who designed that area is reading this, I hate you. I would have slapped you if I was there when you made it.

Lastly the block pushing animation is pretty glitchy for me so it takes a while to push blocks and pots around.

Other than that, it's a beautiful game that I just found myself being absorbed into as I played. It's one of those games where you start playing and then before you even know it, several hours have gone by

reviewText:
This is overall a great game imo. I love the art, the puzzles, great level design, very solid overall. I think there are a few issues that may bother some (not me personally) but should probably be mentione.

Pro:
- Art, nice simple style and smooth 60fps animations.
- Music
- Unique and sometimes Difficult Puzzles that make you think
- Level design
- enjoyable combat reminiscent of Zelda 2 on nes (not too easy but not frustratingly difficult either, (unless you're fighting those blue/green slimes grrr))
- Big fun bosses
- lots of secrets and collectables
- classic metroidvania style with utalizes new skills not only for exploration but also useful skills in combat.
- few extra stages that are optional for those seeking higher challenge
- New game+ for extra replaybility

Cons (well maybe for some not for all, you decide)
- No map system
- lack of direction can make players get lost fairly easily lots of time spend wandering around aimlessly
- Probably need a controller to get the full experience of the game (interface was meant for it, should be interchagable)
- while the atmosphere of the game and presentation are great, if you're looking for a great narative, this is not the place
- using the musicom system to platform was annoying having to stop every platform to play the song was very pace breaking.

I enjoyed it a great deal, have played through it twice, fans of the metroidvania genre will greatly enjoy it
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Excellent metroidvania platformer. Honestly one of the best platformers I have played in years. They really don't make them like this anymore, great level design, interesting and fun game mechanics, tight controls (your skill and timing are the only thing to blame for your failure), good soundtrack, lots of secrets. I put this game on the same level of enjoyment as 'Ori and the Blind Forest'. The aesthetics might not be the same, but this game is intentionally retro. Finding Teddy 2 does not hold your hand. Most of the progression through the game is left up to the player to figure out and find. Personally I enjoy this aspect. If you prefer to have your hand held and be told where to go every step of the way, then this title might not be for you. A gripe I keep reading about this game is the lack of maps. If you play the game past the first 15 minutes, you will discover that the game areas are separated in a way that it's ok that there aren't maps. The areas are not enormous, and they all have half-way portals between the main map and the boss dungeon in case you need to return to the main hub. If you enjoy exploration based metroidvania games with challenging (but not impossible) platforming, then I could not recommend this title more. I thoroughly enjoyed this game, played it exclusively until I beat it, and was terribly sad to see it end. To reiterate, they just don't make games like this anymore, and even fewer of this caliber. I hope this review helps anyone on the fence, thanks for reading.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is very reminiscent of Metroid and Zelda (Zelda II: The Adventure of Link to be specific) and it plays great. The controls are tight and combat fun. When you use the jump + down attack you bounce off their head like a trampoline which leads to some bouncy combos. The dungeons like dungeons within dungeons. Your hub world has rooms to unlock as you collect different abilities and encourages revisiting old areas to get to previously hard to reach treasure boxes. The pixel art and effects are smooth as butter and make the world very attractive to look at. There are no tutorials, no map system (Which I admittedly wish we had) so you can't use the complaint Video games try too hard to hold your hand" because this game definitely lets you fend for yourself. Finding Teddy II is a great game with awesome visuals and gameplay. I highly recommend it."

reviewText: Finding Teddy 2 is an action/adventure game.  If you have played the first Finding Teddy, There are quite a few changes from the point and click game that you know.  There is a lot more exploration and little guidance to where to go, making it quite challenging at times.  But i must say, The controls are solid and the graphics look great  :). reviewText:
Finding Teddy 2 - A Steam Review

[Disclamer - I was provided a copy by the publisher for review purposes]

The good:

Awesome graphics and sounds
One of the most fun metroidvania games I've played in a while.
Lots of secrets, upgrades and enemies to defeat. And jewels, lots of jewels.
Innovative inclusion of sound in puzzles.
The not so good:

Lack of a proper tutorial, I've found myself singing at walls way too many times
A certain kind of enemy with a shield in narrow corridor that made me lose 20 minutes
No keyboard support
The conclusion:

A must have for all the fans of the genre and a should have for people that appreciate a beautiful game with solid gameplay.

You can see me playing it here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rV3daw8C8E

reviewText:
When I started this game I thought it would be a complete joy. All the zelda hype, translate in a lot of languages, that item menu on the load window that I wanted so much to fill completely.

Boy, never have I been so wrong.

I was really wanting to see what the combat would look like since the sword range is really short. I thought that would be a catch to it, but there isnt. What happens is that the enemies are dumbed down and slow so the game is not so hard. Its awful. Almost as bad as zelda 2, but I'd say zelda 2 is a little better.

There is like a trillion maps with no division or organization whatsoever.

Falling from a slightly higher place gives you that small fall set back that completely stops movement and that tottaly kills its flow. If the character could fall and lose a little movement but already continue going forward, like stumbling a little, it would be way way better.

The art style is really fine but in some places is really lacking detail. Its like they tried to make a million different places and were overwhelmed by so much scenarios. There is no style consistency too, I felt like playing an improved version of Tobias and the Dark Sceptres.

Its like that team that have a programmer, an artist, but lacks a designer.

reviewText: This game looks amazing. I was so excited to play and ready for a really cool adventure, as the reviews described. Unfortunately, the description failed to mention that the key configuration is basically unuasable for Mac or PC users without a controller. It is also impossible to rebind the keys, so there is no way to fix this. The movement is set up for Aroow keys and WASD, pretty standard. But the action keys are KLOP and the instructions on how to do extensive commands (ie - running, a necessity) is only explained for controller format (press right bumper") instead of letting the user know that double tapping the movement keys makes her run (also difficult). I had to press every key on the keyboard before I could figure out how to see the inventory. This problem has been brought up in several forums and never been resolved. A simple key rebinding option could fix many problems.\n\nBut not the fact that the opening scene is just a black screen with the words 'press any key to skip'. Which I have read is another ongoing problem. I will definitely watch somone else play the game because I want to see what I'm missing out on
date: but until the config is actually playable it will just feel like a waste of money :("

reviewText:
Finding Teddy 2 is the game for you if you:

-enjoy games that crash frequently, with no autosaves, of course, wouldn't want you keeping your progress when you find a bug
-rather get lost with no idea where to go in an inconsistent world than having a map system
-love backtracking through boring platforming to go through unending red doors, tedious tasks are fun!
-like getting shot by enemies after screen transitions, when you have no control over your character, and if you are lucky you may even be knocked back to the previous screen so you can repeat the cycle, hooray!
-always wanted to try a waiting simulator, simply kill a red slime or rock elemental or try the last 2 bosses
-don't want any description whatsoever about any item you collect or buy
-never want a good story in the games you play, because all you get is a brief intro at the start, no further elaboration on the characters
-use autohotkey since the controls are unconfigurable

On a positive note the visuals, soundtrack and movement physics are pretty good. Musicom was interesting although it did become a chore for the red claws,

Overall this game is just too frustrating to recommend.

reviewText: This is a classic Metroidvania, pure and simple.  Beyond that, the controls are not the tightest for an action platformer but they are more than enough to get the job done.  The pixel animation is gorgeous, almost enough so to make the game worth playing just for that.  Unfortunately, the game suffers from a few disruptive glitches here and there; save frequently and don't pause at inopportune moments, otherwise you may find yourself in big trouble.  I have also had problems with the game crashing from time to time, though I'm not using the most high-end machine.  But despite this, I have found the game to be a very enjoyable romp so far.  Bottom line: if you're a fan of Metroidvanias, like me, then you will almost certainly enjoy this game.  My only other note is that the keyboard controls are kind of counterintuitive; stick to using a controller.

reviewText:
Don't let the beautiful graphics mislead you. It's the only redeeming factor for this game. After making a nice Point'n'Click game with Finding Teddy, Storybird tried their hands on a platformer with puzzle elements in the second installment. Sadly, this idea backfired immensely.
The controls are hellishly unresponsive with your character carrying far too much momentum over when changing direction, especially mid-air. Everything just feels delayed and sluggish. Your first sword is so short, you have to move extremely close to your enemies to hit them. Also, there's a LOT of backtracking involved, but opposed to other Metroidvania-style games, there is no map whatsoever which aids you in finding your way around the world. Top that off with the absolutely abysmal level design, which is completely incoherent. Some sections wrap around with several screens being connected by doors in no sensible way. Most of the time you're running around screen after screen after screen without knowing what to do. Some of those screens serve no gameplay purpose whatsoever. They're just filler scenery.
The Musicom is a concept that was carried over from the first installment. It allows the player to communicate with the environment via musical notes. While this is a great idea, the execution in Finding Teddy 2 only contributes to the amount of frustration and confusion players have to endure while playing this game. The first one had 26 notes which corresponded to the latin alphabet. Communicating was as simple as putting in an english word. Finding Teddy 2 on the other hand introduces some kind of syllable language with 12 symbols (notes of one octave), which look far too similar most of the time. At least there is an in-game dictionary of words, but still this feels more like learning Korean.

All in all, this game is not worth your time, no matter how low the price tag!

reviewText:
In the end, Finding Teddy II will find a core audience with its game, as it's got several strengths to boost from in terms of it's art design/sound design, the exploration part of the game, and what's a solid but not spectaular control and combat system. But the problem comes in the lack of information the game presents to the user: The user is very much on their own in terms of figuring out things, from figuring out what the next thing to do is, to even simple things like finding out how to use your shield. Needless to say: impatient or players who want their hand held need not apply, because it's going to be  a rough go for you with the games lack of direction.

+:
-Beatiful art + seamless animation: makes the world come alive with every step and movement.
-Pixel art works well in terms of presentation.
-Sound/Music design well done.
-Explorer's dream, several secrets.
-Controls are alright when you get used to them.

-:
-Very much on your own. Severe lack of information means a lot of back tracking and probing against walls that may have a room you didn't notice. I don't want to make a connection to a game like Castlevania II: Simon's Quest, but it isn't far from it with the lack of information. With no guides at the moment: that's going to get you stuck.
- Lexicon (musical device) interface could have been done better so person could still play device and see the words that they need to play.
-No bindable keys for keyboard OR controller
-Xbox 360 controller prompts are incorrect. This led to accidentally closing the game without saving it, and problems with attempting to save new settings.
-Impatient players will have a fit with the sword length and lack of control on it. Very much a slow paced game.


For more first impressions and gameplay: http://youtu.be/7uKoZbnyVOg

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BI8a1Xn-1CA

If you were looking for point'n'click similar to the previous game in the series - nope. If  you look for really well made metroidvania platformer with polished style and good feeling of control over the character - that's it. Maybe you won't like it at once - at beggining there's absolutely no tip about what to do or where to go, but with the time exploring vast world will get you some answers. Most of the interactions in the game are based on the Lexicon musical device, that consists of many runes that works same as words. There are also collectibles, some upgrades (for ex. you cannot swim at first nor do wall jump). Playing with keyboard may be little off since you do not jump with space (as always), and there's no redifining the keys. Pad though works just fine.

Still after some time in game, I got that feeling of slight boredom, since walking around to this or that door" is not the great definition of action or puzzle -  which is shame
date: because taking into consideration  previous game devs could make a better job. Walking to get key for door and walking back and opening it does not work as great incentive after few of those situations.\n\nOverall it is really hard to just simply point to "yes" or "no" as for this game.  I guess in this case I'll take it to money factor
recommended: which will point to "NO". I bet you could get possibly fun with sequel but save yor money and wait for discount."

reviewText:
Got three minutes in the game before controls became an issue. Immediately checked out the settings to remap keybindings. It wasn't clear how to, so I went ahead and searched for the answer on Google, and the discussion forums used by Steam.

The consensus is 'you can't.'

Okay, so for someone playing on a home computer basically what I've been told is I need a twenty to thirty dollar peripheral (a controller) to play this game. It'd be psychotic if the publisher were to suddenly offer downloads for Rock Band and conveniently neglect to mention the requirement of third party hardware.

So none of the publishers or developers associated with this software will be getting any of my business unless this problem gets fixed. Well, any more. They already screwed me out of fifteen bucks. I will -happily- take down this review if that gets changed, but until then...be aware.

Kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that another player has to go through the trouble of buying a game first to tell you it's broken, huh?

reviewText:
Have you ever really wanted to love something? It looks like something you’d love, it sounds like something you’d love, and by all rights, it should be something you love, but it’s not. For whatever reason, the stars have maliciously aligned and this Thing You Should Love falls just short of the mark, stumbling in as a bittersweet disappointment, a wasted opportunity, a thing you so easily could have loved, and it stings.

That is how I feel about Finding Teddy II.

reviewText: I've spent a good amount of time in this game, and it's a very good game to invest in. I haven't had this much fun in ages, as well as frustration (but in a good way!) This game has kept me on my toes, having to rethink and revisit the chapters you come across as you go. sometimes it does get a little laggy in terms of fighting, but for the most part it has beautiful graphics, the music is wonderful, and i for one haven't gotten bored playing it :P\n\nI'd say 10/10 graphics, 8/10 for gameplay, and overall solid 9. There are some complications in terms of direction, but I think for the most part that's what makes the game well invested in. You're not spoon fed the answers, you have to literally go back because if anything, there's something you've missed. I've found myself lost a few times, but after revisting places and doing certain things I find the answers eventually. You just need patience is all.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Biased Rating: 9/10

Beautiful music, consistent visuals, and unique, silent storytelling make for a great atmosphere. Finding Teddy 2 plunges you into its world, robs you of your floaty companion, and delivers a great metroidvania experience. Solve puzzles, upgrade your equipment, face bosses—who seem to be allegories for modern, spiritual tribulations—, and find teddy.

I absolutely loved this game. It's so far become my favorite game this year. Combat is finnicky, and some enemies are placed in very spiteful locations, but it definitely remains enjoyable the whole way through. I didn't have that impulse to 100% the game because it's very tedious to do so. Nothing really fun about it in this game.

Either way this was such a great game. I'd definitely recommend it to any fan of the metroidvania genre.

reviewText: Highly recommended if you like action platformers/Metroidvanias.  Combat reminds me of Zelda 2 but much smoother. Beautiful pixel style graphics, challenging, smooth controls, great soundtrack, and lengthy quest make this a definite buy.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I can recommend Finding Teddy 2, although with a rather large asterix. Significant patching has greatly improved the game since launch, eliminating an awful lot of its major issues. After a frankly awful beginning, Finding Teddy 2 winds up being a really satisfying slice of Metroidvania, albeit with some niggling combat issues. It also happens to be one of the best looking pixel art games I've seen in years. It's just a shame that some dodgy controls, troublesome bugs and an initial lack of purpose and direction might put players off discovering the game's later, finer moments.

Still a huge win for anyone looking for challenging puzzles though.


Full review here: http://www.gizorama.com/2015/computer/pc/finding-willpower-finding-teddy-2-review
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Things I loved:
- This game is very atmospheric. The music, sound, and art really set the mood well. The sound of marbles pouring out of a treasure chest is intensely satisfying.
- The abilities you get that let you traverse new parts of old levels are innovative and well-woven into the levels. Even the standard abilities (such as double jump) are fun to use, and beautifully animated.
- There is a secret code language, and I really like the way this game handles it. Rather than a simple substitution cipher (where each symbol stands for one letter) that you have to puzzle out yourself, the code is more complicated. However, whenever you see someone say a word in this secret language, you automically record it and can look it up whenever you want. This removes the need for tedious note-keeping outside the game while still providing a nice mystery.

Areas for improvement:
- Combat was a little clunky sometimes. As far as I can tell, you never get a ranged attack, so you always have to fight in close quarters. Furthermore, many of the enemies in the later game explode into damaging particles when they die, or sometimes hurt you if you try to stab them (or both!) For me, this meant that combat became more frustrating as I progressed.
- The layout of the main dungeons was sometimes a little uninspiring. You often progress in a fairly obvious way of (Go through this door) --> (Find code for next door) --> (Go through next door). I think the worst offender was the 4th main dungeon, which is where I actually stopped playing. I got to the boss once, lost to it, and then it was clear that I had a long trek back to him. I couldn't muster the will to fight back to him through several long corridors.

Even with some frustrations near the end, I heartily recommend this game. If you like exploration and a heavy dose of mystery, you absolutely will not be disappointed. You should also pick up the soundtrack!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: What if the legend of zelda link to the past was a somber, atmospheric game with a slower pace and more backtracking? Well you get Finding Teddy 2. Has that good old indie feel, with the ugly bits too. I personally love this game. The pixel art is gorgeous and the soundtrack is adds to the atmosphere (except the piano in the library, super obnoxious...). However the game suffers most from a control scheme (whether you're on keyboard or controller) that doesn't synergize with the intended playstyle well. A challenge in the game is that your attack distance is very short, so you'll be trying to inch yourself closer to enemies to damage them, but guess what? Double tapping the move controls causes you to sprint. I can't even count the times I faught a shield enemy and tried to tip toe a smidge closer, and wound up bullrushing directly into them for tons of damage. The most painful part is that on the controller at least, there's a run button *as well*. So why the double tap?? Also, the game's difficulty is pretty swingy. Towards the end of the game, there's a lot of waiting that the game suffers from. Tons of fire enemies that will zone you out with fire that lasts several seconds before you can get close, so you just sit there like an idiot until you can take a step forward.\n\nOther than that, it's a fantastic game and I highly recommend it, especially if you love those atmospheric indie pixel games and 8-bit zeldas.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's like Zelda II and Metroid had a baby. I'm sure Castlevania fits in there somewhere too. Great game overall, interesting idea with the Lexicom thing. This is really an adventure game: no compass, no map, very cryptic hints. This game doesn't hold your hand. As long as you pay attention to what the characters say and fully explore areas once new items are acquired you'll do fine. Best $14.99 I've spent on Steam in awhile.

Pros:
Great art style
Fun gameplay
Great controls

Cons:
Some enemies are annoying to hit without you being hit with the limited attack range
No way to toggle run on and off, either you hold down the button or you walk

This is definitely a game I'll be playing more than once.


On another note I found a reproducible bug that you can try at home. If you take too long fighting the third boss the game crashes. Instead of doing the finishing down thrust just wait for it to start attacking you again. A couple cycles of this and it always crashes with a Runtime Error. Not complaining, just found it funny.

voteText: January 4

reviewText: This game is REALLY hard at first because it gives you 0 instruction, but it feels rewarding when you can progress through it. It requires a lot of patience and memory as you can easily get lost in the various worlds, and what makes it harder is that there is no map, and it's barely ever obvious what you need to do next. You'll explore almost every screen possible before you realize you may have missed a door or two, or that you need to revisit old areas if you've gotten a new skill and see how you can cover more ground that way.\n\nI recommend this to anyone who wants to sit back and scratch their head for a few hours trying to solve puzzles and where to use specific items. I do not recommend this to anyone, like myself when I first thought about getting this game, who is looking for a fast paced and linear sidescroller. You're not going to find it here. That was my expectation, it got crushed, but I appreciate the difficulty of this game and would only recommend it to those who really want to commit to taking a lot of time to explore and come up with their own solutions that are hard to find in almost every screen.

reviewText: Exploring and collecting new abilities is a treat, made more enjoyable by the art/sound.  The short range of your attack takes some getting used to, but (much like Cave Story's unusual jump) ultimately helps set this apart from your average platformer.  The lack of a map does make the backtracking necessary in a Metroidvania a little more difficult.  Over-all, a very positive 27 hours...
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: A very fun game!  It reminds me a little bit of Zelda II with a bit of Metroid mixed in.  Each new area, once you get used to it, is easily navigable and there are many branching paths in dungeons.  The game doesn't seem to spend time with a convoluted story, which allows the gameplay to take center stage.  There's a single hub area with four disctinct worlds, each with their own dungeon, sort of like a Zelda game.  The swordplay is reminiscent of Zelda II, except that (as far as I know) your shield seems to be useless.  The enemies start out easy enough, but their placement and abilities grow as the game progresses, which makes for increasingly challenging gameplay.  All in all, I'm rally enjoying Finding Teddy 2, and am probably going to check out the first one.

You should play this game!\n\nNote: It does have kind of a big thematic jump from the first puzzle-oriented game, which was all about making friends, whereas now you beat up a lot more monsters than you befriend, which is a bit of a shame. But the game itself is great if you can separate it from the gooey cuteness of its predecessor!

reviewText: What if the legend of zelda link to the past was a somber, atmospheric game with a slower pace and more backtracking? Well you get Finding Teddy 2. Has that good old indie feel, with the ugly bits too. I personally love this game. The pixel art is gorgeous and the soundtrack is adds to the atmosphere (except the piano in the library, super obnoxious...). However the game suffers most from a control scheme (whether you're on keyboard or controller) that doesn't synergize with the intended playstyle well. A challenge in the game is that your attack distance is very short, so you'll be trying to inch yourself closer to enemies to damage them, but guess what? Double tapping the move controls causes you to sprint. I can't even count the times I faught a shield enemy and tried to tip toe a smidge closer, and wound up bullrushing directly into them for tons of damage. The most painful part is that on the controller at least, there's a run button *as well*. So why the double tap?? Also, the game's difficulty is pretty swingy. Towards the end of the game, there's a lot of waiting that the game suffers from. Tons of fire enemies that will zone you out with fire that lasts several seconds before you can get close, so you just sit there like an idiot until you can take a step forward.\n\nOther than that, it's a fantastic game and I highly recommend it, especially if you love those atmospheric indie pixel games and 8-bit zeldas.

reviewText:
This game is a joy to play, the visuals are brilliant, the soundtrack is lovely, and the amount of things to do will keep you entertained for every cent that is it worth.

The controls however, need some tweaking. Forget playing this on a keyboard, the control scheme is locked and cannot be rebound and are in such odd places on the keyboard using either WASD or the arrows put your hands in pretty uncomfortable situations. Use a controller or gamepad and that problem goes away, but some things still don't work quite right. The jumping, running, ducking, slashing, and sprinting work magnificently, until you get to a point where you need to wall jump. Sometimes the character will hit the wall and the wall jumping works, but most of the time at some point during your chain of jumps, the character will just not hit the wall, or the game will have you double-jump instead ruining the combo and you will likely fall into the abyss. Be prepared to fail wall jump challenges A LOT.

Devs, please please tweak the hitbox for the wall jump, that would be super great.

That being said, do not let that deter you in any way from giving Finding Teddy 2 a try. Overall, it is really a great platformer and does a great job of calling back to the retro days of yore.

reviewText: This game is REALLY hard at first because it gives you 0 instruction, but it feels rewarding when you can progress through it. It requires a lot of patience and memory as you can easily get lost in the various worlds, and what makes it harder is that there is no map, and it's barely ever obvious what you need to do next. You'll explore almost every screen possible before you realize you may have missed a door or two, or that you need to revisit old areas if you've gotten a new skill and see how you can cover more ground that way.\n\nI recommend this to anyone who wants to sit back and scratch their head for a few hours trying to solve puzzles and where to use specific items. I do not recommend this to anyone, like myself when I first thought about getting this game, who is looking for a fast paced and linear sidescroller. You're not going to find it here. That was my expectation, it got crushed, but I appreciate the difficulty of this game and would only recommend it to those who really want to commit to taking a lot of time to explore and come up with their own solutions that are hard to find in almost every screen.

reviewText:
EDITED AS OF 6/4/16

Pretty fun game. Nice controls, nice graphics.

Pros:
Metroidvania style platformer
Controls are tight and responsive
Harkens back to a time when games were difficult, and didn't lead you by the hand to everything (although now as CoT, it has a bit of tutorial. But it is NOT invasive)
Intergrated dash button is MORE THAN welcome, as is the simplistic map
Good audio
Sound being the main idea is a cool concept

Cons:
Metroidvania style platformer; you will be doing A LOT of backtracking
Hit box for your character seems a bit bigger than it should be (combined with your limited range, it can be a nightmare)

Personal Cons (FOR THOSE WITH LIMITED DEXTERITY): As was my complaint when I first bought this: I wish there was a dedicated button for..." That's still the case
